Key Match Events: The Kings were able to score two big buckets that helped them beat Philly 113-107.
De'Aaron Fox (35 points) and Malik Monk (20 points) combined for 55 of Sacramento's 113 points.
On a pivotal Sixers turnover, Fox attacked the rim and hit a lay-up to cut the Sixers lead to four points.
Monk got a pivotal goal-contending call to go his way and put Sacramento permanently in front in this game.
Tyrese Maxey tried to split a double team and got his pocket picked, which created a DeMar DeRozan lay-up which tied this game.
Pre-Game Insights: The Sixers were able to find their offensive rhythm early once again in this contest, led by Paul George who finally ended his shooting slump.
Post-Match Reflections: This was a winnable game that the Sixers let get away from them thanks to poor decision making in the fourth quarter.
Philly's fourth quarter execution left a lot to be desired and that must improve if they want to make a deep playoff run in the postseason.
Miscellaneous Highlights: Paul George had a 30-point scoring night for him, overpowering the smaller Kings defenders and getting them in foul trouble early in this contest.
George has been getting into foul trouble on the defensive end because of his over aggressiveness and some 50/50 foul calls that put him in bad positions.
Others: The Kings to their credit continued to battle back despite the Sixers leading throughout most of this contest.
